The full function signature is torch.bernoulli(input, out=None) → Tensor
When you do a.bernoulli(), this is equivalent to torch.bernoulli(a).
When you do a.bernoulli_(a), this is equivalent to torch.bernoulli(a, out=a) (what you want in your case I think)
When you do a.bernoulli_(float_val=0.5), this function fills each entry of a is a bernouilli with probability float_val which has a default value of 0.5.

To answer your question, when you do a.bernoulli_(), this is equivalent to a.bernoulli_(0.5) and not a.bernoulli_(a) as you were expecting.

body:
The full function signature is `torch.bernoulli(input, out=None) → Tensor`
When you do `a.bernoulli()`, this is equivalent to `torch.bernoulli(a)`.
When you do `a.bernoulli_(a)`, this is equivalent to `torch.bernoulli(a, out=a)` (what you want in your case I think)
When you do `a.bernoulli_(float_val=0.5)`, this function fills each entry of `a` is a bernouilli with probability `float_val` which has a default value of 0.5.

To answer your question, when you do `a.bernoulli_()`, this is equivalent to `a.bernoulli_(0.5)` and not `a.bernoulli_(a)` as you were expecting.
